title: Does the violin ever accompany the piano? - Quora

response.answer_text: The violin accompanies the piano quite often in Ravel’s sonata. Inventive composers like to vary the texture of their music and putting a melody in the piano with a string accompaniment is an excellent way to do this. Plenty of examples in Beethoven, Brahms, Dvorak, Franck … probably Debussy too.

I am not sure about the piano, but I know the violin part is an accompaniment to the guitar for the whole sonata, the Grand Sonata in A major for Guitar and Violin by Paganini![1] Take a look in the music. However, it is alway perform as guitar solo without the violin part, perhaps it is too boring for a violinist or the guitarist feel I don't need it? response.answer_text: Some Mozart Sonatas (particularly the 2nd movement of the No. 33 in E-flat major K. 481) Some Beethoven sonatas David Lang's light moving (commissioned for Hilary Hahn's 27 encores project) has the violin as the piano's accompanist. Several other of the encores in this project have the violin accompanying. The Glass Violin Sonata

In fact, at least some of Beethoven’s violin sonatas are entitled, by the composer, “for Pianoforte and Violin,” showing the piano to be the principal instrument. Furthermore, any classical or later sonata for violin and piano with any degree of sophistication casts both instruments in both soloistic and accompanimental roles.

Yes. As a prime example, listen to Beethoven’s ten violin sonatas. The word “sonata” is misleading since they are really duets for violin and piano. The ninth, known as the Kreutzer sonata, is one of his greatest pieces.
Many (if not all) of Mozart’s sonatas for Violin and Piano are piano solos with violin accompaniment.
